title: Z-score: How Fast Are You?
question_text:
Students in an AP Statistics class wanted to measure how fast, in miles per hour, they could throw a tennis ball into the wall. A student had a standardized score of $1.2$.
If the units were changed from miles per hour to feet per second, what would be the new standardized score?
solution:
A z-score measure how many standard deviations a value is above or below the mean. A z-score standardizes the variable so when the units are changed the z-score still remains the same.

Explanation of Distractors Choice 'A' is incorrect the z-score would remain the same not change to negative. Choice 'B' is incorrect as this would represent if the z-score of $1.2$ was in mph and then converted to feet per second and then changed to a negative value. Choice 'C' is incorrect as the z-score of $1.2$ doesn't change to $0$. Choice 'D' is incorrect as this would represent if the z-score of $1.2$ was in mph and then converted to feet per second

Imagine the average speed of an AP Statistics student throwing a tennis ball against the wall had a mean and standard deviation of $24 \text{ mph}$ and $5\text{ mph}$, respectively. If a student threw the ball at a speed of $30\text{ mph}$ the z-score would be:

$$\text{z-score}=\frac { \text{statistic - parameter} }{ \text{standard deviation of statistic} } =\frac { 30 \text{ mph}-24\text{ mph} }{ 5\text{ mph} } =1.2$$

Notice there are no units as $\text{mph}$ would cancel out from the numerator and denominator.

If we converted miles per hour to feet per second:

$$30 \text{ mph} = \dfrac { 30\text{ miles} }{ 1\text{ hour} } \bullet \dfrac { 1\text{ hour} }{ 60\text{ minutes} } \bullet \dfrac { 1\text{ minutes} }{ 60\text{ seconds} } \bullet \dfrac { 5280\text{ feet} }{ 1\text{ mile} } =44\text{ ft/sec}$$

$$24 \text{ mph} = \dfrac { 24\text{ miles} }{ 1\text{ hour} } \bullet \dfrac { 1\text{ hour} }{ 60\text{ minutes} } \bullet \dfrac { 1\text{ minutes} }{ 60\text{ seconds} } \bullet \dfrac { 5280\text{ feet} }{ 1\text{ mile} } =35.2\text{ ft/sec}$$

$$5 \text{ mph} = \dfrac { 5\text{ miles} }{ 1\text{ hour} } \bullet \dfrac { 1\text{ hour} }{ 60\text{ minutes} } \bullet \dfrac { 1\text{ minutes} }{ 60\text{ seconds} } \bullet \dfrac { 5280\text{ feet} }{ 1\text{ mile} } =7\frac { 1 }{ 3 } \text{ ft/sec}$$

Calculating the z-score using the values for $\text{ft/sec}$:

$$z-score=\frac { \text{statistic - parameter} }{ \text{standard deviation of statistic} } =\frac { 44 \text{ ft/sec} -35.2 \text{ ft/sec} }{ 7\frac { 1 }{ 3 }} =1.2$$

Therefore, we can see the z-scores stay the same when units are changed.
